an4.21:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an4.21:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
an4.21:2.1: “Mendicants, this one time, when I was first awakened, I was staying near Uruvelā at the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.
an4.21:2.2: As I was in private retreat this thought came to mind:
an4.21:2.3: ‘One without respect and reverence lives in suffering.
an4.21:2.4: What ascetic or brahmin should I honor and respect and rely on?’
an4.21:3.2: ‘I would honor and respect and rely on another ascetic or brahmin so as to complete the full spectrum of ethics, if it were incomplete.
an4.21:3.3: But I don’t see any other ascetic or brahmin in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who is more accomplished than myself in ethics, who I should honor and respect and rely on.
an4.21:4.1: I would honor and respect and rely on another ascetic or brahmin so as to complete the full spectrum of immersion, if it were incomplete.
an4.21:4.2: But I don’t see any other ascetic or brahmin … who is more accomplished than myself in immersion …
an4.21:5.1: I would honor and respect and rely on another ascetic or brahmin so as to complete the full spectrum of wisdom, if it were incomplete.
an4.21:5.2: But I don’t see any other ascetic or brahmin in this world … who is more accomplished than myself in wisdom …
an4.21:6.1: I would honor and respect and rely on another ascetic or brahmin so as to complete the full spectrum of freedom, if it were incomplete.
an4.21:6.2: But I don’t see any other ascetic or brahmin in this world … who is more accomplished than myself in freedom …’
an4.21:7.2: ‘Why don’t I honor and respect and rely on the same teaching to which I was awakened?’
an4.21:8.1: And then Brahmā Sahampati, knowing what I was thinking, vanished from the Brahmā realm and appeared in front of me, as easily as a strong man would extend or contract his arm.
an4.21:8.2: He arranged his robe over one shoulder, knelt on his right knee, raised his joined palms toward me, and said:
an4.21:8.3: ‘That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!
an4.21:8.4: All the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas who lived in the past honored and respected and relied on this same teaching.
an4.21:8.5: All the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas who will live in the future will honor and respect and rely on this same teaching.
an4.21:8.6: May the Blessed One, who is the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha at present, also honor and respect and rely on this same teaching.’
an4.21:8.8: Then he went on to say:
an4.21:9.4: destroyer of the sorrows of many—
an4.21:10.2: they did live, they do live,
an4.21:10.4: This is the nature of the Buddhas.
an4.21:11.4: remembering the instructions of the Buddhas.’
an4.21:12.2: Then he bowed and respectfully circled me, keeping me on his right side, before vanishing right there.
an4.21:12.3: Then, knowing the request of Brahmā and what was suitable for myself, I honored and respected and relied on the same teaching to which I was awakened.
an4.21:12.4: And since the Saṅgha has also achieved greatness, I also respect the Saṅgha.”
